awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Mathematical and Theoretical Biology Institute (MTBI)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mathematical and Theoretical Biology Institute (MTBI) summer program trains undergraduates through cutting-edge research and intensive mentoring experiences in the applied mathematical sciences. This eight-week summer research program is open to college juniors and seniors who are interested in learning quantitative methods and carrying out research on intriguing applications of math to their day-to-day lives. It encourages students from minority institutions and/or students from underrepresented groups who come from economically disadvantaged families as well as from local community colleges to apply. The summer program begins with four weeks of concentrated coursework on topics specific to mathematical and computational statistics, and theoretical biology at the advanced undergraduate and graduate level. The daily coursework is paired with coordinated computer labs and collaborative study sessions with graduate student teaching assistants and faculty present. Students are trained in leading computer software such as MATLAB, Mathematica, Maple, Netlogo, and R. During the second half of the program the students are asked to take what they have learned and apply it to group research projects of their choice with help from mentors. These projects are written as technical reports and students give a research presentation on their work/results at ASU during the final week of the program. The students also create posters of their projects that they present first at ASU and then again at the national SACNAS Conference and the Joint Mathematics Meetings. In summary, the exciting MTBI environment generates innovative research projects, leads to the achievement of significant scientific results within a summer, and motivates undergraduate students to pursue higher studies.
  
The objectives of the MTBI Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates program are to encourage and facilitate the access to the successful completion of graduate studies by mostly underrepresented minority (URM) undergraduate students at the interface of mathematics and life and social sciences. The MTBI summer program at ASU exposes undergraduates to scientific research by introducing them to methods in applied mathematics, training them on well-known modeling software and letting them address relevant questions in theoretical biology. The program faculty is composed of first-rate minority, non-minority and international researchers, both  male and female to teach, advise, and mentor MTBI students. All have active research programs. MTBI not only supports an environment in which high quality undergraduate research is recognized and expected but also provides opportunities for students to collaborate on their research with excellent researchers from around the country and world. The program expands the visibility of the research carried out at MTBI by minorities via presentations of student research at national conferences. Success is measured directly by the quality of the student reports, and by the acceptance to and completion of graduate school by our participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
QRLSSP’s broad objectives include:

  • Recruiting U.S. URMs, women, first-generation students and individuals with limited STEM opportunities to careers in the mathematical and biological sciences;
  • Providing students with a real-world, in-depth research experience, familiarizing them with essential computer-based research tools, and introducing them to the demands inherent to pursuing a graduate degree;
  • Exposing students to advanced topics in Applied Mathematics and the mathematical skills encompassed therein;
  • Supporting students in a strong, team-based learning environment, with robust mentoring that allows for the development of a fledgling academic network.

 These ideals serve a higher purpose for both the individual and society.  For the individual, impacts include a greater personal earning potential with enhanced social conditions, a sense of accomplishment and confidence for better career aspirations; a desire to give back and support others who have faced the same challenges as they have.  Societal benefits include increasing representation of traditionally underrepresented groups and minorities, creating a more balanced and representative group of academicians and employees in industry; improving economic conditions; creating more balance among ethnic groups that may result in better and more representative public policy.

 Our specific goals and objectives over the past four program years have included:

 Recruiting U.S. URMs, women, first-generation students and other individuals with limited STEM opportunities in their home institutions;

  • Providing students with an intensive, in-depth research experience, carrying out student-driven research projects in the broad range of social and life sciences;
  • Exposing QRLSSP students to advanced topics and tools from Applied Mathematics applied to quantitative research at a level that will prepare them to engage in undergraduate research;
  • Familiarizing students with current computer tools essential for success in the mathematical sciences, including the symbolic and computational software packages R, Python, Netlogo, XPPAuto, MATLAB, Mathematica, and the document typesetting program LaTeX;
  • Fostering a strong, collaborative learning environment and a bond among the students and faculty to aid them in their summer research and give them a source of support in graduate school and beyond;
  • Cultivating a strong network of quality peer and faculty mentors (both QRLSSP faculty and guests) to the extent that quality mentoring can occur;
  • Providing students insight of what to expect in the pursuit of a PhD through an intensive, rigorous research experience;
  • Strengthening the pool of U.S. URM students, especially those enrolled at non-selective, small, or non-PhD-granting institutions, so they may pursue graduate degrees in the mathematical sciences with a high probability of success;
  • Monitoring the progress of the program alumni to help evaluate the success of the program.

We are pleased to report that each year we assess these tenets to ensure that our REU activities comply with these guidelines and move the program further in its overarching goals.

Over the course of these past several years, we have hosted 93 participants in this program (28 whom were international and were funded entirely by Arizona State University, which added to the diversity and cultural enrichment of the program).  Of the 65 U.S. participants, 38 are underrepresented minority students (Hispanic/Latino, African American, Native American), that is, 58%. An additional 14 (22%) are members of underrepresented groups in STEM (White and Asian females).  29 have entered graduate programs, 13 of whom are URM (45%).  Many of these students are still undergraduates; we will continue to monitor their career paths to determine actual graduate degree attainment and success, as well as to support them in the pursuit of their professional endeavors.  NOTE:  The program years included are 2018, 2019, 2021, and 2022.  The 2020 program was held entirely online due to the pandemic and did not use NSF funding.
